quizzes.title: History Quiz: War and Decade
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, people, june. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What decade saw the Great Depression, Adolf Hitlers election as Chancellor of Germany, and the outbreak of World War II?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1930s

questions.question: These wars for the English throne were fought between 1455 and 1485.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wars of the Roses

questions.question: These wars were fought in France between French Catholics and Protestants in the second half of the 16th century.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Huguenot Wars

questions.question: More than seventy million people were killed in this war, which made it the deadliest conflict of all time.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: World War II

questions.question: This war took place between September 26, 1959 and April 30, 1975 as part of the Cold War conflict.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Vietnam War

questions.question: Martin Luther King, Jr., John F. Kennedy and Robert F. Kennedy were assassinated during this decade.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1960s

questions.question: This war, which took place in Europe in the first half of the 17th century, is one of the deadliest conflicts in history.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thirty Years War

questions.question: During this decade, MTV was launched, the Chernobyl accident happened, and NBA star Michael Jordan rose to fame.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1980s

questions.question: This war started on June 25, 1950 as a civil war and grew into a proxy war between the participants in the Cold War.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Korean War

questions.question: During this decade there was an oil crisis, the Apollo 13 space mission was carried out, and the first modern computers were invented.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1970s

questions.question: Which of the Punic wars was fought between 264 and 241 BC in Sicily and Africa?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: First Punic War

questions.question: The participants in this war never came to the point of a direct military clash, but fought indirectly through espionage, propaganda and competition in various fields.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cold War

questions.question: In this decade the Panama Canal was built, mass production of the automobile began, and the home phonograph became popular.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1900s

questions.question: The Triple Entente and the Triple Alliance were the belligerent parties in this war which broke out in 1914.

options.text: The War to End All Wars

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: These wars were fought between 1803 and 1815, and included the famous battles of Austerlitz and Waterloo.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Napoleonic Wars

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Wwii and Us
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, election, athletes. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What year did the Wright Brothers fly at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1903

questions.question: During WWII, the booming defense industries and the shortage of labor opened substantial new job opportunities in the US for this group of people.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Both

questions.question: During WWII, this major weapons development project had facilities in New Mexico, Washington state, and Oak Ridge, Tennessee.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Atomic bomb

questions.question: When did the American Civil War break out?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1861

questions.question: What did American children often do during WWII to contribute to the war effort?

options.text: They took part in basic military training
Gathered scrap metal, rubber, etc. that could be recycled.
They worked part time in munitions factories.
Provided aircraft observers to help their adult counterparts spot enemy airplanes.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gathered scrap metal, rubber, etc. that could be recycled.

questions.question: What year did George Washington win his first victory against Hessian Soldiers at Trenton New Jersey?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1776

questions.question: This Christmas song, first sung by Bing Crosby, became number one on the hit parade and a favorite of troops abroad in the Christmas seasons of 1942 through 1944.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: White Christmas

questions.question: Before the attack on Pearl Harbor, WWII had been fought for well over two years in Europe and even longer between Japan and China. Though officially neutral, what did the US do to help friendly nations?

options.text: Sent US Marines to help the Chinese nationalists
Sent part of the US Army Air Force fleet of B17 bombers to help the British
Provided the Soviet Union with raw materials
Protected British convoys in the Atlantic

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Protected British convoys in the Atlantic

questions.question: Which of the following US cities was hit by shell fire or bombing during WWII?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Honolulu

questions.question: During WWII, besides money, what else did you need in order to buy a scarce product such as gasoline in the US?

options.text: A certificate from the national rationing bureau
A ration coupon for the product
A sworn statement that the product was essential to you

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A ration coupon for the product

questions.question: During WWII, famous athletes, movie stars, and other celebrities often made appearances to encourage Americans to do which of the following?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Buy war bonds

questions.question: President Roosevelt met with other Allied leaders several times at several places during WWII. Which is the only leader he met in the White House in Washington?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Winston Churchill

questions.question: What statement is true about the US Presidential election scheduled in the midst of the war for November 1944?

options.text: It was canceled and Roosevelt allowed to continue as President.
It had five voting days instead of one to give people a better chance to vote.
It was delayed until the Japanese surrender.
It was carried out without any significant changes.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: It was carried out without any significant changes.

questions.question: During WWII rubber was in short supply since the Japanese took over some of the best rubber producing areas. What measures were taken in the US to curtail the use of rubber by civilians?

options.text: Speed limits on highways were lowered to reduce wear on tires.
Gasoline was rationed to reduce travel and therefore reduce wear on tires.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: What year did “Custers Last Stand (Battle of the Little Bighorn) take place?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1876

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Year and October 13th
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, onwards, halleys. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This Sound of Silence singer was born on October 13th in 1941.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Paul Simon

questions.question: From 1594 onwards, the development of Volley Fire began to have a critical impact. Count William Louis wrote a letter, describing what he had learned from the drill practice used by the Ancient Roman armies, as described by writers such as Aelian. To whom did he send this letter?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Count Maurice

questions.question: Which country in Europe had the first large permanent military force in Europe?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Spain

questions.question: What year was Ronald Reagan elected President of the United States for the first time?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1980

questions.question: On October 13th, 1941, former Axis power, Italy, declared war on Germany.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: October 13th 1582 does not exist in Poland.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: What year did Franklin D. Roosevelt and Adolph Hitler come to power?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1933

questions.question: What year did Rita Hayworth, Fred Astaire and Liberace die?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1987

questions.question: When did the Cuban Missile Crisis start?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1962

questions.question: On October 13th, 1971, Major League Baseball history was made when the first night game of a World Series was played between the Pittsburgh Pirates and this team.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Baltimore Orioles

questions.question: Name the French-language daily newspaper in Canada, whose first edition hit the streets of Montreal on October 13th, 1884.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: La Presse

questions.question: This really really big variety show host died on October 13th in 1974.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ed Sullivan

questions.question: The Hindenburg Disaster in Lakehurst, New Jersey took place in the same year that the fabric Nylon was invented. What year was that?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1937

questions.question: What year marks Halleys Comet first appearance in the 20th century?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1910

questions.question: Until 1494, wars were protracted and relatively bloodless, the sieges of towns slow and uncertain. However, war erupted in 1494 when the massive use of cannon made sieges last hours. To what event does this refer?

options.text: The French invasion of the English held counties of  Normandy  Aquitaine
The Dutch siege of  s Hertogenbosch

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The French invasion of Italy

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Caligula and Battle
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, saw, defeat. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Who played Caligula in the self-titled movie, released by Penthouse International in 1979?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Malcolm McDowell

questions.question: King Frederick V of Bohemia is often referred to as the Winter King because of his short reign.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: What did the name Caligula originally refer to?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: little boots

questions.question: In what battle did the Highlanders have their last successful charge?

options.text: Bonnie Prince Charlie at  Falkirk in 1745-46 campaign
Marquis of Motnrose  Alastair MacColla at Kilsyth in 1644-45 campaign

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Heights of Abraham in 1759

questions.question: The French were first to use chemical weapons, during the  World War I.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: What is the name of the centurion who assassinated Caligula?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cassius Chaerea

questions.question: Caligula almost caused a crisis in the  province of Judea, when he ordered that an image of himself be placed in the Jewish temple in Jerusalem.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Caligula succeeded this emperor, who died in March of 37 A.D.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tiberius

questions.question: The period between 1500 - 1800 saw wars transform from wars of attrition to wars of extermination.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: What is meant by Brandschatzung (translated as Firemoney)?

options.text: Pillaging occupied territory in order to obtain supplies for the army
Supplying an army under the threat of being accused as heretics
Hiring mercenary armies as protection against pillaging
Demanding supplies under threat of torching or pillaging

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Demanding supplies under threat of torching or pillaging

questions.question: Which submarine was used by the Germans on May 7,1915, during the attack on one of the most impressive luxury ships ever built, the ocean liner RMS Lusitania?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: U - 20

questions.question: To what period does the Terror refer to?

options.text: The rule of the Legislative Assembly - 1791 - 1792
The rule of the National Constitutional Assembly - 1789 - 1791
The rule of the Legislative Assembly - 1793 - 1794

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The rule of the Legislative Assembly - 1793 - 1794

questions.question: Galleys undoubtedly revolutionized the War at Sea, the main reason being the far superior fire power over any other sea-going ship at the time. On October 7th, 1571 for the first time galleys were in the forefront of a major sea battle. Which battle was this?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Battle of Lepanto

questions.question: In 1598 the Imjin war in Asia ended with a devestating defeat of the Japanese Navy by the Allied Korean and Chinese Navies, ending the Japanese invasion of Korea. In what battle was the Japanese fleet decisively defeated?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The battle of Noryang

questions.question: What was the name of Caligulas pet horse?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Incitatus

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Patent and System
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, kg, bird. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Who made the first flashlight?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Joshua Lionel Cowen

questions.question: In 1976 the US Patent Office issued a patent for an inflatable rug.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: In 1982 the US Patent Office issued a patent  for a face mask that was designed to stop people from eating.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Samuel F. B. Morse invented the telegraph key.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: This chemical weapon was first used during World War I in the Second Battle of Ypres, April 22, 1915, when the Germans attacked French, Canadian and Algerian troops.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chlorine

questions.question: The United States Supreme Court declared that this man invented the radio.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: N. Tesla

questions.question: What did Ivan Getting and Bradford Parkinson develop?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: GPS

questions.question: The first effective depth charge, developed in 1916, was a 300-pound (140 kg) barrel-like casing, containing high explosive.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: In 1999 the US Patent Office issued a patent for a bird diaper.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Who is given credit for inventing the neon light?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Georges Claude

questions.question: The main use of this air craft was in reconnaissance over the North Sea and the Baltic during World War I.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Zeppelins

questions.question: What do the letters in laser stand for?

options.text: Light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation
Light amplification and synchronic electric radiance

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation

questions.question: Who made the first light bulb?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Joseph Swan

questions.question: A standard, incandescent light bulb emits light when a filament is heated. How does a fluorescent bulb  work?

options.text: Light is emitted when a mercury filament reacts with great pressure inside a glass bulb.
Light is emitted when argon gas reacts with an electrical current.
Light is emitted when solar energy reacts with a silk thread.
Light is emitted when mercury vapor is heated.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Light is emitted when mercury vapor is heated.

questions.question: In 1793 Claude Chappe made the first system of communicating over long distances via flags. What word refers to such a system?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Semaphore

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Gallipoli and Anzacs
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, cape, invention. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which of these games came first?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Frogger

questions.question: This official Australian war historian was responsible for creating the Anzac legend of resourcefulness, mateship and courage.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: C.E.W. Bean

questions.question: The acronym ANZAC means Australian New Zealand Army Corps.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Before arriving at Gallipoli, the Anzacs trained in what country?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Egypt

questions.question: The Battle of Lone Pine was an important battle of the Gallipoli campaign. How many Anzacs died to capture Lone Pine?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Over 2000

questions.question: The elograph, which was invented  in 1971, was the basis of what device?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Touch screen technology

questions.question: The term digger, was applied to Australian soldiers because they dug trenches at Gallipoli to escape enemy fire.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Which of these conditions were not present at Gallipoli at the time of World War I?

options.text: In winter, the weather was freezing with temperatures often falling below zero. Rain and snow made life miserable for the soldiers.
In summer, Gallipoli was very hot and dry with an inadequate supply of water.
The soldiers lived in trenches which they dug themselves while under fire from the enemy.
The trenches were always kept clean by the soldiers to lessen the outbreak of diseases.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The trenches were always kept clean by the soldiers to lessen the outbreak of diseases.

questions.question: Which statement is true about the Regency?

options.text: It was the first auto with an automatic transmission.
It was the first cell phone.
It was the first auto with a moon roof.
It was the first transistor radio.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: It was the first transistor radio.

questions.question: What everyday item was invented by Will Mueller in 1935?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Automatic telephone answering machine

questions.question: Which of the following was introduced by the Western Union Compnay in 1933?

options.text: Sending money across the country by wire.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The singing telegam

questions.question: When the Anzacs evacuated the Gallipoli Peninsula in December 1915, 25 men were killed as they climbed into the boats that were waiting to take them to the ships offshore.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Which of these was an invention of Charles Strite?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The pop-up toaster

questions.question: In 1915, the Anzacs were supposed to land at Cape Tepe but they landed two kilometres to the north.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Who had the great idea of putting  a bell on the telephone so people would know that someone was calling?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thomas Watson
